project.title: OMG - Ontology for Managing Geometry
project.creator: Anna Wagner, Mathias Bonduel & Pieter Pauwels

tabs.title: 0: OMG introduction
tabs.description:
This is a simple app to visualize and communicate the content of a knowledge base in the RDF format. The project is open source, and we welcome all who is interested to participate. Please find the Github repository [here](https://github.com/MadsHolten/sparql-visualizer).

The frontend of the app is based on [Angular](https://angular.io/), [material design](https://material.angular.io/) and [D3](https://d3js.org/) and the default local triplestore is based on [rdfstore](https://github.com/antoniogarrote/rdfstore-js). Since rdfstore does not fully support SPARQL 1.1 and has no reasoning capabilities, it is recomended to use a [Stardog](https://www.stardog.com/) based triplestore instead.
### Use a Stardog triplestore
To use the app with a Stardog triplestore this sparql-visualizer app must either be available online, or it must run in a local environment. You can find the instructions for installing a local version of this app under [Detailed installation guide](https://github.com/MadsHolten/sparql-visualizer)
With a local copy of the app running, make sure you have a Stardog running (defaults to port 5820) with an empty database (let's call it 'test'), so that you don't delete anything important. Then click the "Switch to triplestore" button and type in "http://localhost:5820" as endpoint and "test" as database. If you haven't changed the username and password they both default to "admin".
### Use the default local triplestore
This will work, but beware that some queries will not run properly, and INSERT/DELETE will not be possible.
### Resources
*[Documentation](https://www.w3.org/TR/sparql11-query/)

*[Online course in Linked Data Engineering](https://open.hpi.de/courses/semanticweb2016)

tabs.title: 1a: OMG geometry L1 - intro
tabs.query:
PREFIX bot: <https://w3id.org/bot#>
PREFIX omg: <https://w3id.org/omg#>
PREFIX ex: <http://example.org/columns#>

CONSTRUCT
WHERE{
	#bot:elements with simple geometry descriptions (L1) directly connected
	?elementWithSimpleGeometry a bot:Element ;
		omg:hasSimpleGeometryDescription ?simpleDescription .
	#any bot:element in the graph
	?element a bot:Element .
}
tabs.description:
## Part 1 - Working with geometry using OMG (L1)
A selection of the sample triples are visualized in the graph based on the CONSTRUCT query. 

This tab shows the sample data that will be used within the following tabs of part 1. It shows all instances of `bot:element` (four columns) and simple geometry descriptions that are directly linked to them (Level 1 or L1). It is also possible to connect a complex, RDF-based geometry description (e.g. using the GEOM ontology) directly to an object, but this not shown in this example.

**NOTE!** Don't forget to load the sample triples in your local Stardog, if you plan to go through the following tabs of part 1. Click on "Load dataset" (main graph) after having setup the correct endpoint, database name, username and password of your Stardog instance.

tabs.title: 1b: SELECT all directly connected geometry
tabs.description:
## Part 1 - Working with geometry using OMG (L1)


A SPARQL select query is used to extract every `bot:Element` that is directly connected to a simple or complex geometry with its geometry description value.

tabs.title: 1c: INSERT simple geometry description
tabs.description:
## Part 1 - Working with geometry using OMG (L1)


A new `bot:Element` (`ex:newColumn`) is added and given a simple geometry description "some new STEP geometry".

tabs.title: 1d: Replace existing geometry description
tabs.description:
## Part 1 - Working with geometry using OMG (L1)


The geometry description of the in 1c added `bot:Element` (`ex:newColumn`) is changed to "some changed STEP geometry".

tabs.title: 1e: DELETE existing geometry description
tabs.description:
## Part 1 - Working with geometry using OMG (L1)


The geometry description of the original column (`ex:column1`) is removed.

tabs.title: 1f: Review changes
tabs.query:
PREFIX bot: <https://w3id.org/bot#>
PREFIX omg: <https://w3id.org/omg#>
PREFIX ex: <http://example.org/columns#>

CONSTRUCT
WHERE{
	#bot:elements with simple geometry descriptions directly connected
	?elementWithSimpleGeometry a bot:Element ;
		omg:hasSimpleGeometryDescription ?simpleDescription .
	#any bot:element in the graph
	?element a bot:Element .
}
tabs.description:
## Part 1 - Working with geometry using OMG (L1)


To visualise the changes that were made in the previous steps (1b-1e), this tab visualises the manipulated graph, consisting of a `bot:Element` without geometry description (deleted geometry) and the newly added element with its changed geometry description.

tabs.title: 2a: OMG geometry L2 - intro
tabs.description:
## Part 2 - Working with geometry using OMG (L2)
A selection of the sample triples are visualized in the graph based on the CONSTRUCT query. 

This tab shows the sample data that will be used within the following tabs of part 2. It shows all instances of `bot:element` (two columns) and simple & complex geometry descriptions that are linked to them via a middle node (Level 2 or L2).

**NOTE!** If you plan to go through the following tabs of part 2, you're advised to delete the content of the main graph ("Wipe graph") before loading the sample triples. Click on "Load dataset" (main graph) after having setup the correct endpoint, database name, username and password of your Stardog instance.

tabs.title: 2b: SELECT all L2 geometry
tabs.query:
PREFIX bot: <https://w3id.org/bot#>
PREFIX omg: <https://w3id.org/omg#>
PREFIX ex: <http://example.org/columns#>

SELECT ?element ?geometryDescription
WHERE{
	?element omg:hasGeometry ?geometry .
	?geometry omg:hasSimpleGeometryDescription|omg:hasComplexGeometryDescription ?geometryDescription .
}
tabs.description:
## Part 2 - Working with geometry using OMG (L2)

A SPARQL select query is used to extract every element that is connected to a simple or complex geometry via an intermediate geometry node. The complex geometry description is not extracted in full detail but just its first node.

If Stardog is used, the query of 2a can be written shorter using the '|' sign (OR).

tabs.title: 2c: INSERT new geometry and geometry description
tabs.description:
## Part 2 - Working with geometry using OMG (L2)

A new geometry is added to `ex:column3` with the simple geometry description "some new STEP geometry" as an RDF literal.

tabs.title: 2d: Replace existing geometry description
tabs.description:
## Part 2 - Working with geometry using OMG (L2)

The original glTF JSON geometry description of `ex:column2` is changed to "some changed glTF json".

Note that the intermediate geometry node of `ex:column2` - `ex:geometry1` - links to two simple geometry descriptions and that it is not possible to query for only the one linking to the RDF literal containing the glTF JSON (and not the accompanying glTF bin). The [FOG ontology](http://w3id.org/fog) defines subproperties of `omg:hasSimpleGeometryDescription` to make it possible to query for a specific geometry file.

tabs.title: 2e: DELETE existing geometry description
tabs.description:
## Part 2 - Working with geometry using OMG (L2)

The COLLADA geometry description of `ex:column3` is removed, including its intermediate geometry node `ex:geometry2`.

tabs.title: 2f: Review changes
tabs.description:
## Part 2 - Working with geometry using OMG (L2)

To visualise the changes that were made in the previous steps, this tab visualises the manipulated graph. It now contains the same two columns. One of the two geometry descriptions linked to the intermediate `ex:geometry1` node of `ex:column2` has a changed glTF JSON literal. The `ex:column3` has a new geometry node (`ex:newGeometry`) and a new STEP literal.

tabs.title: 3a: OMG geometry L3 - intro
tabs.description:
## Part 3 - Working with geometry using OMG (L3)
A selection of the sample triples are visualized in the graph based on the CONSTRUCT query. 

This tab shows the sample data that will be used within the following steps. Using geometry of L3 (level 3) allows to version them: between the intermediate geometry node and the actual geometry description, is an additional geometry state node. 

The sample data contains one column (`ex:column4`) with four geometries connected: two of them link via a geometry state to a simple geometry description, while the other two link to a complex geometry description. The last geometry node (`ex:geometry7`) links to two geometry state nodes.

The current geometry states are of type `omg:CurrentGeometryState`.

**NOTE!** If you plan to go through the following tabs of part 3, you're advised to delete the content of the main graph ("Wipe graph") before loading the sample triples. Click on "Load dataset" (main graph) after having setup the correct endpoint, database name, username and password of your Stardog instance.

tabs.title: 3b: SELECT all L3 geometry
tabs.description:
## Part 3 - Working with geometry using OMG (L3)

A SPARQL select query is used to extract every `bot:Element` that is connected to a simple or complex geometry description via an intermediate geometry and geometry state node. Only the most recent geometry state (`omg:CurrentGeometryState`) is queried for.

The complex geometry descriptions are not extracted in full detail but just its first node.

If Stardog is used, the query of 3a can be written shorter using the '|' sign (OR).

tabs.title: 3c: INSERT new geometry, state and geometry description
tabs.description:
## Part 3 - Working with geometry using OMG (L3)

A new geometry node and state is added to `ex:column4`. The new geometry state is directly the `omg:CurrentGeometryState` and links to a simple geometry description "some new STEP geometry".

tabs.title: 3d: Add a new current geometry state with a simple geometry description
tabs.description:
## Part 3 - Working with geometry using OMG (L3)

The original DWG geometry description of `ex:column4` is changed to "some changed DWG geometry". This requires to remove the `omg:CurrentGeometryState` of the old geometry state and to create a new current geometry state and a linked geometry description. Additional metadata about the state can be added, at least containing the time of creation.

A geometry state can be part of a group (`omg:Context`) of geometry state and/or geometry nodes containing related geometry descriptions. In the example, this was the case for the old geometry state, and this context will be added to the new geometry state.

tabs.title: 3e: Changing a complex geometry description on property level
tabs.description:
## Part 3 - Working with geometry using OMG (L3)

The height of the bounding box (`ex:geometry7`) of `ex:column4` is changed on property level using the [OPM ontology](https://w3id.org/opm#)). Thus, no new geometry state is added but any derivation-related relations (`omg:isDerivedFromGeometryState`) must be deleted, since this geometry no longer is originally derived.

tabs.title: 3f: Changing a complex geometry description on object level
tabs.description:
## Part 3 - Working with geometry using OMG (L3)

The position of the complex geometry description (on the current geometry state of `ex:geometry6`) is changed by adding an (empty) `geometry:Transformation` node containing the complete description. As a result, a new current geometry state is created. 

The transformation will not contain a transformation matrix as the purpose of this demonstrator is to show how to model using OMG and not the geometric description itself. 

The newly added geometry object as well as all geometry objects connected to it need to be connected to the geometry state using `omg:containsGeometryObject` and since the transformation is the upper node of the geometry description, the geometry state must relate to it with `omg:hasComplexGeometryDescription`. Additionally, the `omg:Context` is also transmitted to the new geometry state.

tabs.title: 3g: Deleting an existing geometry state
tabs.description:
## Part 3 - Working with geometry using OMG (L3)

A new geometry state for the L3 OBJ geometry description of `ex:column4` is created and marked as being `opm:Deleted`. The previously defined values and relations are still stored in the now deprecated geometry state.

tabs.title: 3h: Review changes
tabs.description:
## Part 3 - Working with geometry using OMG (L3)

To visualise the changes that were made in the previous steps, this tab visualises the manipulated graph. The graph still contains `ex:column4`, which now has five geometries: three simple and two complex geometries. Each geometry has at least one geometry state and one of them is deleted.

tabs.title: 4a: Grouping geometry using a omg:Context - intro
tabs.query:
PREFIX bot: <https://w3id.org/bot#>
PREFIX omg: <https://w3id.org/omg#>
PREFIX ex: <http://example.org/columns#>
PREFIX geometry: <http://rdf.bg/geometry.ttl#>

CONSTRUCT
WHERE { ?s ?p ?o }
tabs.description:
## Part 4 - Grouping geometry using omg:Context
A selection of the sample triples are visualized in the graph based on the CONSTRUCT query. 

This tab shows the sample data that will be used within the following tabs. It contains three columns, each with one geometry node. Each geometry has only one geometry state: one links to simple geometry descriptions (two literals) and the other two link to complex geometry descriptions.

The `omg:Context` node `ex:highDetail` is used to group two geometry nodes and one geometry state node.

**NOTE!** If you plan to go through the following tabs of part 4, you're advised to delete the content of the main graph ("Wipe graph") before loading the sample triples. Click on "Load dataset" (main graph) after having setup the correct endpoint, database name, username and password of your Stardog instance.

tabs.title: 4b: SELECT every element, geometry and description of each omg:Context
tabs.description:
## Part 4 - Grouping geometry using omg:Context

A SPARQL select query is used to extract every building element, geometry, optional geometry state and the connected simple or complex geometry descriptions (L2 and L3) that are connected to the same context. The complex geometry description is not extracted in full detail but just its first node.

tabs.title: 4c: SELECT every geometry description grouped in one specific omg:Context
tabs.query:
PREFIX bot: <https://w3id.org/bot#>
PREFIX omg: <https://w3id.org/omg#>
PREFIX ex: <http://example.org/columns#>
PREFIX geometry: <http://rdf.bg/geometry.ttl#>

SELECT ?geometryOrGeometryState ?geometryDescription
WHERE{
	?geometryOrGeometryState omg:hasContext ex:highDetail .
  	?geometryOrGeometryState omg:hasSimpleGeometryDescription|omg:hasComplexGeometryDescription ?geometryDescription .
}
tabs.description:
## Part 4 - Grouping geometry using omg:Context

A SPARQL select query is used to extract every building element, geometry, optional geometry state and the connected simple or complex geometry descriptions (L2 and L3) that are connected to the same context. The complex geometry description is not extracted in full detail but just its first node.

tabs.title: 4d: INSERT a new omg:Context
tabs.query:
PREFIX bot: <https://w3id.org/bot#>
PREFIX omg: <https://w3id.org/omg#>
PREFIX ex: <http://example.org/columns#>
PREFIX geometry: <http://rdf.bg/geometry.ttl#>

INSERT{
	?newContext a omg:Context .
	?geometryNode omg:hasContext ?newContext .
	?geometryState omg:hasContext ?newContext .
}
WHERE{
	BIND(ex:newContext AS ?newContext)
	BIND(ex:geometry1 AS ?geometryNode)
	BIND(ex:geometryState3 AS ?geometryState)
}
tabs.description:
## Part 4 - Grouping geometry using omg:Context

A new context is added and linked towards a L2 and L3 geometry description on geometry (`ex:geometry1`) resp. geometry state (`ex:geometryState3) level.

tabs.title: 4e: DELETE a omg:Context
tabs.description:
## Part 4 - Grouping geometry using omg:Context

The original context is deleted including all its incoming and outgoing relations.

tabs.title: 4f: Review changes
tabs.query:
PREFIX bot: <https://w3id.org/bot#>
PREFIX omg: <https://w3id.org/omg#>
PREFIX ex: <http://example.org/columns#>
PREFIX geometry: <http://rdf.bg/geometry.ttl#>

CONSTRUCT
WHERE{
	?s ?p ?o
}
tabs.description:
## Part 4 - Grouping geometry using omg:Context

To visualise the changes that were made in the previous steps, this tab visualises the manipulated graph, consisting of a new `omg:Context`, while the previous `omg:Context` was deleted.

tabs.title: 5a: Complementing and transforming geometries - intro
tabs.description:
## Part 5 - Complementing and transforming geometries
A selection of the sample triples are visualized in the graph based on the CONSTRUCT query. 

This tab shows the sample data that will be used within the following tabs of part 5. It contains two column with geometry nodes that either complement or transform each other. The complemented and original geometry nodes are not depicted in further detail, since the geometry description itself is not relevant for this case. However, the translated geometry must contain a transformation or translation matrix as shown.

**NOTE!** If you plan to go through the following tabs of part 5, you're advised to delete the content of the main graph ("Wipe graph") before loading the sample triples. Click on "Load dataset" (main graph) after having setup the correct endpoint, database name, username and password of your Stardog instance.

tabs.title: 5b: SELECT transformed and complemented geometry
tabs.description:
## Part 5 - Complementing and transforming geometries

A SPARQL select query is used to extract every geometry that either complements or transforms another geometry with their base geometry as well as the type of relation between them.

tabs.title: 5c: INSERT a new relation between two geomtries
tabs.description:
## Part 5 - Complementing and transforming geometries

A new relation between two geometries is added with `omg:complementsGeometry`. The method is the same for the `omg:transformsGeometry` relation *BUT* the transforming geometry should have no geometric description apart of a transformation/translation matrix.

tabs.title: 5d: DELETE an existing relation between two geometries
tabs.description:
## Part 5 - Complementing and transforming geometries

A relation (`omg:complementsGeometry`) between two geometries is removed.

tabs.title: 5e: Review changes
tabs.description:
## Part 5 - Complementing and transforming geometries

To visualise the changes that were made in the previous steps, this tab visualises the manipulated graph, consisting one transforming and one complementing relation.

tabs.title: 6a: Element properties depending on geometry - intro
tabs.description:
## Part 6 - Element properties depending on geometry
A selection of the sample triples are visualized in the graph based on the CONSTRUCT query. 

This tab shows the sample data that will be used within part 6. It contains one column with two properties (`ex:height` and `ex:volume`) depending on geometry (resp. explicitly and implicitly derived). If a property is explicitly derived from (complex) geometry, it will infer the property state from the complex geometry property.

**NOTE!** For *each tab* of part 6, you need to use a Stardog triplestore. You're advised to delete the content of the main graph ("Wipe graph") before loading the sample triples. Click on "Load dataset" (main graph) after having setup the correct endpoint, database name, username and password of your Stardog instance.

** NOTE!** This 6th part demands the use of reasoning in every tab (incl. this one). Add the [OMG ontology](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tudaIIB/omg/master/omg.ttl) to a named graph in your [running Stardog database](localhost:5820) and do not forget to turn reasoning on in the query component of the SPARQL-visualizer (lower right hand corner). If the query returns no results, press the "Reset" button in the query component and reactivate "Reasoning".

tabs.title: 6b: SELECT dependent properties
tabs.description:
## Part 6 - Element properties depending on geometry

A SPARQL select query is used to extract two geometry-dependent building element properties. In the case of an implicitly derived property, the query returns the base geometry. In the case of an explicitly derived property, the value of the inferred property state is returned.

** NOTE!** This 6th part demands the use of reasoning in every tab (incl. this one). Add the [OMG ontology](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tudaIIB/omg/master/omg.ttl) to a named graph in your [running Stardog database](localhost:5820) and do not forget to turn reasoning on in the query component of the SPARQL-visualizer (lower right hand corner). If the query returns no results, press the "Reset" button in the query component and reactivate "Reasoning".

tabs.title: 6c: INSERT new dependent properties
tabs.query:
PREFIX bot: <https://w3id.org/bot#>
PREFIX omg: <https://w3id.org/omg#>
PREFIX ex: <http://example.org/columns#>
PREFIX geometry: <http://rdf.bg/geometry.ttl#>
PREFIX seas: <https://w3id.org/seas/>
PREFIX opm: <https://w3id.org/opm#>
PREFIX schema: <http://schema.org/>

INSERT{
	?newImplProperty omg:isImplicitlyDerivedFrom ?implGeometry ;
		a opm:Property .
	?newExplProperty omg:isExplicitlyDerivedFrom ?explGeometryProperty ;
		a opm:Property .
	?element seas:hasProperty ?newExplProperty,?newImplProperty .
}
WHERE{
	BIND(ex:newImplProperty AS ?newImplProperty)
	BIND(ex:newExplProperty AS ?newExplProperty)
	BIND(ex:geometry4 AS ?implGeometry)
	BIND(ex:box3length AS ?explGeometryProperty)
	BIND(ex:column4 AS ?element)
}
tabs.description:
## Part 6 - Element properties depending on geometry

Two new `opm:Property` instances are created and linked to geometries for derivation. When adding the `omg:isExplicitlyDerivedFrom` relation, there is no need to also add the `omg:hasInferredPropertyState` relation, as it is a chain property that will be inferred by the reasoner.

** NOTE!** This 6th part demands the use of reasoning in every tab (incl. this one). Add the [OMG ontology](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tudaIIB/omg/master/omg.ttl) to a named graph in your [running Stardog database](localhost:5820) and do not forget to turn reasoning on in the query component of the SPARQL-visualizer (lower right hand corner). If the query returns no results, press the "Reset" button in the query component and reactivate "Reasoning".

tabs.title: 6d: DELETE a dependency relation
tabs.query:
PREFIX bot: <https://w3id.org/bot#>
PREFIX omg: <https://w3id.org/omg#>
PREFIX ex: <http://example.org/columns#>
PREFIX geometry: <http://rdf.bg/geometry.ttl#>
PREFIX seas: <https://w3id.org/seas/>
PREFIX opm: <https://w3id.org/opm#>
PREFIX schema: <http://schema.org/>

DELETE{
	?property omg:isImplicitlyDerivedFrom ?geometry .
}
WHERE{
	BIND(ex:volume AS ?property)
	BIND(ex:geometry6 AS ?geometry)
}
tabs.description:
## Part 6 - Element properties depending on geometry

A `omg:isImplicitlyDerivedFrom` relation between a building element property and a geometry is removed.

** NOTE!** This 6th part demands the use of reasoning in every tab (incl. this one). Add the [OMG ontology](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tudaIIB/omg/master/omg.ttl) to a named graph in your [running Stardog database](localhost:5820) and do not forget to turn reasoning on in the query component of the SPARQL-visualizer (lower right hand corner). If the query returns no results, press the "Reset" button in the query component and reactivate "Reasoning".

tabs.title: 6e: Review changes
tabs.description:
## Part 6 - Element properties depending on geometry

To visualise the changes that were made in the previous steps, this tab visualises the manipulated graph.

** NOTE!** This 6th part demands the use of reasoning in every tab (incl. this one). Add the [OMG ontology](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tudaIIB/omg/master/omg.ttl) to a named graph in your [running Stardog database](localhost:5820) and do not forget to turn reasoning on in the query component of the SPARQL-visualizer (lower right hand corner). If the query returns no results, press the "Reset" button in the query component and reactivate "Reasoning".

tabs.title: 7a: Retrieve the current timestamp of a geometry state - intro
tabs.query:
PREFIX bot: <https://w3id.org/bot#>
PREFIX omg: <https://w3id.org/omg#>
PREFIX ex: <http://example.org/columns#>
PREFIX geometry: <http://rdf.bg/geometry.ttl#>
PREFIX seas: <https://w3id.org/seas/>
PREFIX opm: <https://w3id.org/opm#>
PREFIX schema: <http://schema.org/>

CONSTRUCT
WHERE{
	ex:geometryState2 a omg:GeometryState .
	ex:geometryState5 a omg:GeometryState ;
		omg:containsGeometryObject ?geometryObject ;
       	omg:hasComplexGeometryDescription ?geometryObject ;
		omg:containsPropertyState ?propertyState .
	?geometryObject seas:hasProperty ?property .
	?property opm:hasPropertyState ?propertyState .
	?propertyState a opm:CurrentPropertyState .
}
tabs.description:
## Part 7 - Retrieve the current timestamp of a geometry state
A selection of the sample triples are visualized in the graph based on the CONSTRUCT query. 

This dataset shows geometry states with a RDF-based geometry description. The geometry states link to the top node of the complex geometry (`omg:hasComplexGeometryDescription`), all contained geometry objects (`omg:containsGeometryObject`) and property states (`omg:containsPropertyState`).

This first tab shows the sample data that will be used within the following tab of part 7. It contains two geometry states, one of which contains several property states. For better visualisation this query will only retrieve results from the `ex:geometryState2` (no contained property states or geometric objects) and `ex:geometryState5` (several contained property states and geometric objects).

**NOTE!** For *each tab* of part 7, you need to use a Stardog triplestore. You're advised to delete the content of the main graph ("Wipe graph") before loading the sample triples. Click on "Load dataset" (main graph) after having setup the correct endpoint, database name, username and password of your Stardog instance.

** NOTE!** This 7th part demands the use of reasoning in every tab (incl. this one). Add the [OMG ontology](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tudaIIB/omg/master/omg.ttl) to a named graph in your [running Stardog database](localhost:5820) and do not forget to turn reasoning on in the query component of the SPARQL-visualizer (lower right hand corner). If the query returns no results, press the "Reset" button in the query component and reactivate "Reasoning".

tabs.title: 7b: Retrieve the current timestamp of a geometry state
tabs.description:
## Part 7 - Retrieve the current timestamp of a geometry state
Both the timestamp of the geometry state and the property states it contains are queried for, and the most recent timestamp is returned. A change to a property of a contained geometry does not result in a new geometry state, but only in a new property state. As a result, the timestamp of the contained property state might be more recent then the timestamp of the geometry state containing it.

Note that the `omg:containsPropertyState` relation is inferred using a property chain axiom on the `omg:containsGeometryObject` to each geometry object of the complex geometry description.

** NOTE!** This 7th part demands the use of reasoning in every tab (incl. this one). Add the [OMG ontology](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tudaIIB/omg/master/omg.ttl) to a named graph in your [running Stardog database](localhost:5820) and do not forget to turn reasoning on in the query component of the SPARQL-visualizer (lower right hand corner). If the query returns no results, press the "Reset" button in the query component and reactivate "Reasoning".

tabs.title: 8a: Identify discrepancies in the graph - intro
tabs.description:
## Part 8 - Identify discrepancies in the graph
A selection of the sample triples are visualized in the graph based on the CONSTRUCT query. 

The sample data contains one column (`ex:column4`) with three geometry nodes (`ex:geometry5`, `ex:geometry6` and `ex:geometry7`). Each geometry node has one geometry state.

**NOTE!** For *each tab* of part 8, you need to use a Stardog triplestore. You're advised to delete the content of the main graph ("Wipe graph") before loading the sample triples. Click on "Load dataset" (main graph) after having setup the correct endpoint, database name, username and password of your Stardog instance.

** NOTE!** This 8th part demands the use of reasoning in every tab (incl. this one). Add the [OMG ontology](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tudaIIB/omg/master/omg.ttl) to a named graph in your [running Stardog database](localhost:5820) and do not forget to turn reasoning on in the query component of the SPARQL-visualizer (lower right hand corner). If the query returns no results, press the "Reset" button in the query component and reactivate "Reasoning".

tabs.title: 8b: SELECT outdated geometries and their origin
tabs.description:
## Part 8 - Identify discrepancies in the graph

A SPARQL select query is used to identify discrepancies. The dependencies between the geometry nodes is defined as such that only one is the source geometry (`ex:geometry6`) as only this one appears in the right column.

**NOTE!** For *each tab* of part 8, you need to use a Stardog triplestore. You're advised to delete the content of the main graph ("Wipe graph") before loading the sample triples. Click on "Load dataset" (main graph) after having setup the correct endpoint, database name, username and password of your Stardog instance.

** NOTE!** This 8th part demands the use of reasoning in every tab (incl. this one). Add the [OMG ontology](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tudaIIB/omg/master/omg.ttl) to a named graph in your [running Stardog database](localhost:5820) and do not forget to turn reasoning on in the query component of the SPARQL-visualizer (lower right hand corner). If the query returns no results, press the "Reset" button in the query component and reactivate "Reasoning".

tabs.title: 8c: Update derived geometry
tabs.description:
## Part 8 - Identify discrepancies in the graph

The geometry state of `ex:geometry3` is updated using the same query as shown in tab 3d.

**NOTE!** For *each tab* of part 8, you need to use a Stardog triplestore. You're advised to delete the content of the main graph ("Wipe graph") before loading the sample triples. Click on "Load dataset" (main graph) after having setup the correct endpoint, database name, username and password of your Stardog instance.

** NOTE!** This 8th part demands the use of reasoning in every tab (incl. this one). Add the [OMG ontology](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tudaIIB/omg/master/omg.ttl) to a named graph in your [running Stardog database](localhost:5820) and do not forget to turn reasoning on in the query component of the SPARQL-visualizer (lower right hand corner). If the query returns no results, press the "Reset" button in the query component and reactivate "Reasoning".

tabs.title: 8d: SELECT outdated geometries and their origin
tabs.description:
## Part 8 - Identify discrepancies in the graph

This tab contains the same query as tab 8b. This time two outdated geometries are identified with 1 resp. 2 geometries they could be derived from. However, even though `ex:geometry7` can be derived from two geometries, one of the origins is outdated itself and thereby should not be used.

**NOTE!** For *each tab* of part 8, you need to use a Stardog triplestore. You're advised to delete the content of the main graph ("Wipe graph") before loading the sample triples. Click on "Load dataset" (main graph) after having setup the correct endpoint, database name, username and password of your Stardog instance.

** NOTE!** This 8th part demands the use of reasoning in every tab (incl. this one). Add the [OMG ontology](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tudaIIB/omg/master/omg.ttl) to a named graph in your [running Stardog database](localhost:5820) and do not forget to turn reasoning on in the query component of the SPARQL-visualizer (lower right hand corner). If the query returns no results, press the "Reset" button in the query component and reactivate "Reasoning".

tabs.title: 8e: Review changes
tabs.description:
## Part 8 - Identify discrepancies in the graph

To visualise the changes that were made in the previous steps, this tab visualises the manipulated graph.

**NOTE!** For *each tab* of part 8, you need to use a Stardog triplestore. You're advised to delete the content of the main graph ("Wipe graph") before loading the sample triples. Click on "Load dataset" (main graph) after having setup the correct endpoint, database name, username and password of your Stardog instance.

** NOTE!** This 8th part demands the use of reasoning in every tab (incl. this one). Add the [OMG ontology](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tudaIIB/omg/master/omg.ttl) to a named graph in your [running Stardog database](localhost:5820) and do not forget to turn reasoning on in the query component of the SPARQL-visualizer (lower right hand corner). If the query returns no results, press the "Reset" button in the query component and reactivate "Reasoning".
